headline.print_headline: FDA Approves Appetite-Zapping Implant for Obese Patients
headline.main: FDA Approves Appetite-Zapping Implant for Obese Patients

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have approved an appetite-suppressing implant designed to treat obesity by zapping nerves that connect the stomach and the brain.
docs.snippet: Federal regulators have approved an appetite-suppressing implant designed to treat obesity by zapping nerves that connect the stomach and the brain.

headline.print_headline: New Bronx Senior Center Aims to Provide a More Welcoming Atmosphere
headline.main: New Bronx Senior Center Aims to Provide a More Welcoming Atmosphere

docs.abstract: Services and Advocacy for GLBT Elders receives $1.2 million from New York City to expand senior programs; plans to open new senior center in Bronx, expand its Harlem center and work with other organizations to help LGBT seniors in Brooklyn and Staten Island.
docs.lead_paragraph: The space, which will offer programs and hot lunches, is part of a $1.5 million expansion of services for older lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.
docs.snippet: The space, which will offer programs and hot lunches, is part of a $1.5 million expansion of services for older lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

keywords.value: Services and Advocacy for GLBT Elders (SAGE)
keywords.name: organizations

headline.print_headline: Tiny Cokes: Less Guilt Means More Money for Makers
headline.main: Tiny Cokes: Less Guilt Means More Money for Makers

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans want to cut back on soda, and they're willing to pay more to do it.
docs.snippet: Americans want to cut back on soda, and they're willing to pay more to do it.

headline.print_headline: Obese Preschoolers May Slim Down With Head Start, Study Says
headline.main: Obese Preschoolers May Slim Down With Head Start, Study Says

docs.lead_paragraph: Head Start programs have been shown to help poor children do better in school, but they may also help them fight obesity, a study suggests.
docs.snippet: Head Start programs have been shown to help poor children do better in school, but they may also help them fight obesity, a study suggests.
